newsitem.title: USA: Judge blocks N. California transit strike.
newsitem.headline: Judge blocks N. California transit strike.

text.p: A judge on Monday granted California Gov. Pete Wilson's request for a 60-day cooling off period to avert a strike by Bay Area Rapid Transit (BART) District workers in the San Francisco area.

Wilson, a Republican, had directed state Attorney General Dan Lungren to seek an injunction to prevent any work stoppages. The request was granted by Contra Costa County Superior Court Judge Peter Spinetta.
The injunction will take effect on Tuesday and stay in place until September 6, prohibiting BART workers from striking and administrators from ordering a lock-out.

"It's evident that a BART strike would cause increased traffic congestion and cause distress to the residents of the Bay area," Wilson said in a statement. "It is our view that both sides do not have irreconcilable issues and that a cooling-off period is warranted."
A total of 2,800 workers had threatened to strike because of the contract dispute. BART's collective bargaining agreement for train operators, station agents and other employees expired on June 30.
